title.narrative: Protecting children from the impact of harsh weather conditions through the provisions of NFIs

description.narrative:
Syria is the largest and most dynamic and humanitarian crisis affecting children in the world today. In 2017, an estimated 13.5 million people, including 6 million are in hard-to-reach, including close to 600,000 people in besieged areas.
The onset of winter and summer brings additional suffering and hardship upon the most affected population particularly IDPs living in tented camps, abandoned or unfinished building. Keeping children warm in subzero temperatures and cool during extreme heat is a challenge for the families due to lack of access to electricity, fuel and poorly insulated houses, schools and shelters. Children are particularly vulnerable and are suffering from heat and cold related diseases. Without access to essential NFIs, fuel or electricity, over 5.8million children are at risk of exposure to harsh weather, including acute respiratory infection due to indoor pollution. The provision of heating facilities, winter clothes and blankets can be a lifesaving response for children living in the makeshift tents, open shelter, abandoned or unfinished buildings particularly those in mountainous regions where temperatures dip below freezing points.
The key priority for UNICEF is to protect vulnerable boys and girls living in Syria from the consequences of harsh weather by procuring locally winter clothes kits and blankets and by ensuring timely distribution before the beginning of winter. The procurement and distribution of winter clothes is conducted according to equity and quality standards defined by UNICEF. Kits will be procured entirely at local level to support local markets and economies, and will be distributed to children in need in various areas of the country, both through direct distribution and through inter-agency convoys to reach hard to reach and besieged areas. Specific attention will be paid to children living in the besieged areas and IDPs fleeing from Ar Raqqa and Deir Ez Zor during to the military operations in both governorates in Syria.
Beneficiary targeting will be based on access, social economic vulnerability and extreme weather, with priority being given to child and female headed households, IDPs living in informal settlement, camps, and abandoned or unfinished buildings. Population residing in hard to reach or besieged and contested areas are particularly vulnerable and in greater need of humanitarian assistance since they have limited access to humanitarian assistance and markets.
